Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: With only an hour left in the shift, they are still a few sales short of the weekly target.
Story: I glance at the clock on my desk—just an hour left in my shift, and I’m still three sales short of my weekly target. My manager’s words echo in my mind: “We need everyone to hit their numbers this week.” I know if I don’t, I’ll get that disappointed look and maybe lose out on the weekend bonus. My phone buzzes. It’s a message from Alex: “Hey, which night do you want to go out? I’m free all week, just want to spend some time together.” I feel a pang of guilt. We’ve both been so busy, and I promised we’d have a real date this week. He’s been patient, but I can sense he’s hoping for more than just a quick dinner squeezed between work. My headset feels heavier as I stare at the screen, torn between dialing another number and replying to Alex. I want to be the girlfriend who makes time, but I also need to be the employee who delivers. My heart pounds as I weigh the expectations pressing in from both sides, unsure which role to answer first.
